title: Wednesday, 15th August 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am

Welcome, I guess.

This is Markets Live, the definition of doing the same thing again and again while expecting different results.

Soundbuy Morning
DRichi Good morning
Bluesky21 Practice makes perfect?

Where to begin? Dunno. It's still August. Market's flatlining, news is uninspiring.

How you want to value price gouging shortages is another question as they don't tend to last too long. Still .... Here's Numis to summarise where we are.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The margin performance in Injectables remains impressive, and to have
grown US generic revenues at a time when peers have recently reported significant declines is testament to a more diverse portfolio. 46% growth in MENA Injectables is for us outstanding, and within Branded 31% growth in Egypt is also highly encouraging, offsetting a decline in Algeria.

BE11:20am

15% upgrades for FY18, +2% for FY19 due to the one-offness of it.

BE11:20am

The shares have performed well in the run up to these results, and the
company has delivered the beat and raise needed to justify the shares doubling over the last 6 months, in our view. Our SOTP-based valuation increases to 1,730p (was 1,560p), and with the shares trading, after upgrades, on 21x P/E (at 1,790p) we remain Hold, with the shares price reaction so far this morning (+9%) generous given the oneoff nature of upgrades.

sparrowhawk @soundbuy double that!
11:21 am
BE11:21am

And Caz.

BE11:21am

We note the Non-Injectables guidance upgrade implies a stronger H1 vs.
H2 on the top line, which we believe may reflect the ritonavir 180-day exclusivity expiring (though we think this only expires in September, as Q3 should be bigger than Q2), as well as continued double-digit price erosion. On profitability, the guidance also assumes higher R&D spend in the second half. For the Injectables guidance, the company is benefitting from Injectable Opioid shortages, due to Pfizer’s manufacturing issues. We believe the guidance may be somewhat conservative, allowing for Pfizer to come back in H2 and, hence, including a lower contribution for Hikma from this opportunity in the second half. We believe Injectables guidance also assumes a stepup in R&D in H2.

BE11:23am

You'll remember Hikma's setbacks with generic Advair have been its millstone. No change to guidance of submitting an updated response to the FDA as early as possible in 2019

11:27 am

Sorry, sorry .... macro analysis.

BE11:28am

Let me check the inbox for "Brexit"

BE11:28am

Ah -- here we go. SocGen.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

We are approaching the endgame of the Brexit negotiations prior to exit. The supposed deadline to complete the withdrawal agreement is the October EU summit, but we are sceptical that a deal can be struck by then. The December summit seems more likely. A deal with the EU looks probable, but there is a serious risk that the UK parliament would reject it. If so, then Theresa May would be ousted as leader of the Conservatives, with Boris Johnson currently the frontrunner to succeed her. That would result in the UK crashing out to trade under WTO rules, which would deliver an uncertainty shock to the economy. We think a new leader would be reluctant to hold a snap general election, instead preferring to tough out the aftermath of the exit. We see an 80% chance of a deal and then ratification. A second referendum remains little more than a pipedream of the Remain camp.

wayneJ Perhaps it will be a Daily Mail front page - Black Swan shows bullish signs for Brexit....
BE11:29am

Soft Brexit appears most likely (58%), followed by a Hard Brexit (24%) but with a WTO Brexit, i.e. a cliff-edge exit, still a worryingly high 18%.

BE11:29am

Ah, 58 per cent. Super. Thanks.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Wait! There's a chart!

Excel Developer #AlbertEdwardsOnUKHousing: "Separately, Albert Edwards, an economist from the French investment bank Société Générale, said UK home prices could drop by as much as 12 percent as the property bubble gradually deflates. British real estate surged more than 50 percent over the past decade amid the post-crisis recovery."
BE11:31am

Excel Developer "Edwards said the Bank of England's (BoE) easy money policies of the past decade (with base interest rates as low as 0.25-0.5 percent) had spurred a debt-fuelled demand for housing. Meanwhile, open-border immigration policies made it easy for non-UK citizens to park their money in prime real estate in the UK."
Excel Developer "What you are doing is lending them more money, backed by the taxpayer, to push up house prices even more," Edwards said.
Bluesky21 Is Boris not already running a semi-official leadership campaign? First the burka piece to attract attention, and then the stamp duty piece to ingratiate himself with Tory party members?
BE11:32am

And onto the eco stuff.

wayneJ The chart does no consider the EU ratification process nor the WTO process for the UK to get the required quotas in a no deal scenario.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

In our 2014 study, Quantifying Brexit: It would cut UK growth by over
½% pa, we expected this impact to last for roughly ten years as the economy took time to adjust the new trading conditions. It could easily be longer.
We make no pretence of precision in this estimate. Rather, the simple point is that Brexit is a mistake but one that is unlikely to be reversed. Being outside the EU is almost certain to provide an inferior economic environment that will hurt growth materially, even it is ‘soft’ rather than ‘hard’.

Excel Developer Re No Deal scares, HMG has given itself Henry VIII powers and can hastily approve new sources of food and medicine if required.
BE11:32am

The above comments apply if the exit is smooth. If we crash out without a deal, chaos would be likely to ensue, which would probably deliver a serious shock to activity. One would hope that the folly of this situation would soon be realised and action quickly taken to ameliorate it. However, the economy would not emerge unscathed. We would expect the Bank of England to repeat its action of August 2016, following the referendum result, and ease policy.

Soundbuy Black Swan event will probably happen during AV hols..........leaving us rabble bereft of spiritual guidance........
BE11:33am

All of which, I'm sure, is useful to someone.

wayneJ The other issue with the '1/2%' or whatever off GDP is that it will not be evenly distributed so there could be parts of the country which get 2 - 5% hits to GDP.

BE11:38am

Goldman:

BE11:39am

The sell-off in Chinese equities has continued today (CSI SSE index are down by c.2%) even as the PBOC conducted 383b yuan of MLF (1y, 3.3%), 46.5b yuan more than the expiring 336.5b yuan - a dovish sign.
Despite the continued dovish signs from the policymakers, the commods miners have remained in the penalty box as the market remains concerned about: a) the ongoing EM growth concerns and b) the continued decline in yuan. Until this is resolved, we believe that investors are likely to remain cautious on the commodities / miners.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Copper, also, worth watching.

BE11:40am

It's taking a bath on EM stuff, but also on the possibility that BHP reaches an agreement with unions at Escondida.

Flaneur @Cheeky - link?
BE11:41am

Sides have reached broad agreement over a deal, so there's a worry abouy removing that choke point to copper production too.

Soundbuy Nickel near a 6 month low.........
11:41 am
BE11:42am

Citi's Q2 copper thing's out today.

BE11:42am

2Q18 mined copper under Citi coverage was 2.31mt, a ~8% YoY increase, driven by a combination of ramp-ups, strong operating performance and higher ore grades. Similarly, production volumes, including private companies, rose by ~6% YoY.
Citi coverage copper volumes increased by ~5% QoQ, driven by higher throughput, grades and strong operating performance.
2Q18 Citi equity coverage copper volumes beat our expectations by ~2%, implying an annualised ~1% surplus to our 2018 global supply forecast.
High production levels are generally unsupportive of prices, but the copper price has continued to rise since 2Q16. This might be explained by scrap restrictions in China, raising demand for the primary metal, and also the medium-term demand support from EVs potentially raising the market's demand growth expectations.

Excel Developer Russell Napier (author of Anatomy of a Bear) warns Turkey default to eclipse Lehman because Turkey recovery rates expected to be very low.
BE11:43am

And BMO for a flip view.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The net [copper] short position in COMEX futures and options swelled to ~30,000 as of August 7 as trend followers pile into the bearish trade. The price movement in copper (and other base metals for that matter) seems to be driven by financial markets, and lacks fundamental basis, in our view. We simply have to look to commodities set by the physical market (chrome, vanadium, tungsten, steel rebar) to find price robustness reflecting underlying demand that seems to be okay. Regarding copper specifically, the looming deficit of 415kt forecast this year will, in our view, cause substitution, new higher cost projects, and greater scrap substitution, all of which demand a higher price than where copper is currently trading.

undefined
Swedish Chef There is no majority in Parliament for any Brexit option. So any attempt to quantify outcomes at this sage (24% for a hard Brexit etc) is nonsense. Keeps the sixth formers busy on their school hols work experience though.

But is nearing a conclusion so you'd hope losses are capped now. Here's UBS.

BE11:51am

H118 profit from operations came in at £66m (PY: £39m) vs UBSE of £70m and pre-ex PTP came in at £56m (PY: £22m) vs UBSE of £54m on the back of lower finance charges. Construction margins were 1.1% (+40bps y/y) despite a £15m loss from the AWPR contract (0.5% margin impact). This project is now, finally, near completion. H1 average cash was solid at £161m (PY: £45m). Management expects target margins to be delivered fully in H218 and as a result expects FY18 results to be in line with expectations.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Guidance implies FY18 revenues of £7.7bn (UBSE £8.0bn) and margin guidance by segment is consistent with prior guidance. Partly offsetting this is lower finance costs (now guided for £25m vs UBSE £32m), putting overall performance on track to meet consensus expectations despite the additional £15m loss from the AWPR project. Average net cash guidance is raises to £140-170m (was £120-150m), despite higher cash out on closing out the AWPR contract (£135m vs £105-120m previously). Overall the balance sheet is very strong: average net cash, pension surplus (£184m at H1) and £1,185m NPV value of Investment portfolio.

wayneJ (1) Turkey having a balance of payments / FX crisis does not mean a country default. (2) The issue is what debt is with the govt vs the private sector.
A. M. As someone pointed out to me earlier today, should things take a turn for the worse in Turkey, Erdogan may decide to renege on the refugee agreement.

wayneJ (I am not saying that Turkey won't default - it is just not 100% clear cut).

BE11:52am

We maintain our Dec’18 PBT of £138m (wide consensus range
£135m-£167m), reflecting the impact of lower planned
Investment disposals, reducing interest assumptions and
Aberdeen. However, upside risk in key earnings businesses given
clear margin targets. Shares trading on 14.7x Dec’19 and yield
2.7%. If we strip out Investments (62% market cap), underlying
C&S trading on 6x 2018 EPS – too cheap.
